subsection.title: Writing an Algebraic Expression

assemblage.title: Algebraic expression
assemblage.p: An algebraic expression, or simply an expression, is any meaningful combination of numbers, variables, and operation symbols.

subsection.title: Sums
subsection.p: When we add two numbers a and b, the result is called the sumsum of a and b. We call the numbers a and b the termstermof the sum of the sum.

statement.p:
Write sums to represent the following phrases.
Six more than x
Fifteen greater than r

subsection.p: The terms can be added in either order. We call this fact the commutative law for addition.

assemblage.title: Commutative Law for Addition
assemblage.p: If a and b are numbers, then \blert{a+b = b+a}

subsection.title: Products
subsection.p: When we multiply two numbers a and b, the result is called the product of a and b. The numbers a and b are the factors of the product.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: In arithmetic we use the symbol \times to denote multiplication. However, in algebra, \times may be confused with the variable x. So, instead, we use a dot or parentheses for multiplication, like this:

If one of the factors is a variable, we can just write the factors side by side. For example, ab~~~~\amp \text{means} \amp\amp \text{the product of}~~ a~~ \text{times}~~ b 3x~~~~\amp \text{means} \amp\amp \text{the product of}~~ 3~~ \text{times}~~ x

statement.p:
Write products to represent the following phrases.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: In the previous Example, 10z = 10 \cdot z = z \cdot 10, because two numbers can be multiplied in either order to give the same answer. This is the commutative law for multiplication.

assemblage.title: Commutative Law for Multiplication
assemblage.p: If a and b are numbers, then \blert{a \cdot b = b \cdot a}

subsection.p: In algebra, we usually write products with the numeral first. Thus, we write 10z for "10 times z‚Äù.

subsection.title: Differences
subsection.p: When we subtract b from a the result is called the differencedifference of a and b. As with addition, a and b are called termsterm.

warning.p: The difference 5-2 is not the same as 2-5. When we translate "a subtracted from b," the order of the terms is important. \begin{aligned} b-a~~~~\amp \text{means} \amp\amp a~~ \text{subtracted from}~~ b\\ x-7~~~~\amp \text{means} \amp\amp 7~~ \text{subtracted from}~~ x\\ \end{aligned} The operation of subtraction is not commutative.

subsection.title: Quotients
subsection.p: When we divide a by b the result is called the quotient of a and b. We call a the dividend and b the divisor. In algebra we indicate division by using the division symbol, \div, or a fraction bar.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: The operation of division is not commutative. The order of the numbers in a quotient makes a difference. For example, 12 \div 3 = 4 but 3 \div 12 = \dfrac{1}{4}.

subsection.title: Evaluating an Algebraic Expression
subsection.p: An algebraic expression is a pattern or rule for different versions of the situation it describes. We can replace the variable by specific numbers to fit a particular situation.

assemblage.title: Evaluation
assemblage.p: Substituting a specific value into an expression and calculating the result is called evaluating the expression.

statement.p: Fernando has three roommates, and his share of the rent is \dfrac{R}{4}, where R is a variable representing the total rent on the apartment. If Fernando and his roommates find an apartment whose rent is $540, we can find Fernando's share of the rent by replacing R by \alert{540}. \dfrac{R}{4} = \alert{540} \div 4 = 135 Fernando's share of the rent is $135.

subsection.p: In the previous Example, we evaluated the expression \dfrac{R}{4} for R=540.

subsection.title: Some Useful Algebraic Formulas
subsection.p: Here are some examples of common formulas. Formulas may involve several different variables.

assemblage.title: Distance
assemblage.p: To find the distance traveled by an object moving at a constant speed or rate for a specified time, we multiply the rate by the time. \blert{\text{distance} = \text{rate} \times \text{time}~~~~~~~~~~~~~d = rt}

statement.p: How far will a train moving at 80 miles per hour travel in three hours?

solution.p: We evaluate the formula with r=\alert{80} and t=\alert{3} to find d \amp = rt \amp = (\alert{80})(\alert{3}) = 240 The train will travel 240 miles.

assemblage.title: Profit
assemblage.p: To find the profit earned by a company we subtract the costs from the revenue. \blert{\text{profit} = \text{revenue} - \text{cost}~~~~~~~~~~~~~P = R-C}

statement.p: The owner of a sandwich shop spent $800 last week for labor and supplies. She received $1150 in revenue. What was her profit?

solution.p: We evaluate the formula with R=\alert{1150} and C=\alert{800} to find P \amp = R-C \amp = \alert{1150}-\alert{350} = 350 The owner's profit was $350.

assemblage.title: Interest
assemblage.p: To find the interest earned on an investment we multiply the amount invested (the principal) by the interest rate and the length of the investment. \blert{\text{interest} = \text{principal} \times \text{interest rate} \times \text{time}~~~~~~~~~~~~~I=Prt}

statement.p: How much interest will be earned on $800 invested for 3 years in a savings account that pays 5\dfrac{1}{2}% interest?

solution.p: We evaluate the formula with P=\alert{800}, r=\alert{0.055}, and t=\alert{3} to find I \amp = Prt \amp = \alert{800} \times \alert{0.055} \times \alert{3} = 132 The account will earn $132 in interest.

assemblage.title: Percent
assemblage.p: To find a percentage or part of a given amount, we multiply the whole amount by the percentage rate. \blert{\text{part} = \text{percentage rate} \times \text{whole} ~~~~~~~~~~~~~P=rW}

statement.p: How much ginger ale do you need to make 60 gallons of a fruit punch that is 20% ginger ale?

solution.p: We evaluate the formula with r=\alert{0.20} and W=\alert{60} to find P \amp = rW \amp = \alert{0.20} \times \alert{60} = 12 You would need 12 gallons of ginger ale.

assemblage.title: Average
assemblage.p: To find the average of a collection of scores, we divide the sum of the scores by the number of scores. \blert{\text{average score} = \dfrac{\text{sum of scores}}{\text{number of scores}} ~~~~~~~~~~~~~A=\dfrac{S}{n}}

statement.p: Bert's quiz scores in chemistry are 15, 16, 18, 18, and 12. What is his average score?

solution.p: We evaluate the formula with S=\alert{15+16+18+18+12} and n=\alert{5} to find A \amp = \dfrac{S}{n} \amp = \dfrac{\alert{15+16+18+18+12}} {\alert{5}} = 15.8 Bert's average score is 15.8.

statement.p: What does it mean to evaluate an expression?

answer.p: To substitute a specific value into the expression and calculate the result.

statement.p: How do we change a percent to a decimal fraction?

answer.p: Move the decimal point 2 places to the left.

subsubsection.title: Activity 2: Evaluating Algebraic Expressions
subsubsection.p: EXAMPLE: The Appliance Mart is having a store wide 15%-off sale. If the regular price of an appliance is P dollars, then the sale price S is given by the expression S=0.85P What is the sale price of a refrigerator that regularly sells for $600?
Solution: We substitute \alert{600} for the regular price, P, in the expression. S \amp = 0.85P \amp = 0.85(\alert{600}) = 510 The sale price is $510.
